data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Language and linguistic meaning
data.desc:
Language can be understood as a historically determined system, or form, through which the members of a community express themselves and communicate with one another by means of a specific linguistic code—that is, a set of written signs (symbols) and/or spoken signs (sounds). A language is therefore a system of communication composed of various subsystems. The principal components of a language include the lexicon, the phonological system, morphology, syntax, and pragmatics; when both spoken and written forms are present, a writing system must also be considered.
Linguistics is the discipline devoted to the study of languages, with the aim of understanding the uniquely human capacity for language. Ferdinand de Saussure was the first scholar to endow linguistics with empirical methods and with the scientific objectivity characteristic of the natural sciences. His theories, later collected under the designation of structuralism, earned him recognition by many as the founding figure of modern linguistics.

data.title: Conflict
data.desc:
Conflict can be defined as any form of confrontation that generates violence, whether material or symbolic. It constitutes a state of opposition, a persistent condition that permeates society.
Conflict is not confined to war or overt clashes; rather, it emerges within the spaces of collective life as friction, as an ongoing confrontation among different needs, systems, and worldviews.
It manifests itself within cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures.

data.title: Ferdinand de Saussure
data.desc: Ferdinand de Saussure, research and description.

data.title: Other types of conflict
data.desc:
Conflict may be defined as an incompatibility between what an individual desires, according to the pleasure principle, and what can actually be realized, according to the reality principle.
Intrapersonal conflict: arises within a single individual, taking the form of an inner struggle.
Interpersonal conflict: occurs between two or more individuals, as a situation of confrontation among persons.
Intergroup conflict: emerges between distinct groups, such as teams, companies, or organizations.
Interorganizational conflict: develops between different organizations or institutions.

data.title: Conflicts of Language and Culture
data.desc: different languages, different realities, different truths.

data.title: The Tower of Babel
data.desc: “The Tower of Babel marks two distinct periods in human history: an initial, primordial age of happiness, when humanity shared a single common and universal language, and a subsequent historical period, characterized by the multiplication and wide dispersion of languages.”

data.title: Man Lives in a Symbolic Universe
data.desc:
Every organism possesses both a receptive system and an active system.
The receptive and active systems together constitute the functional cycle of the animal.
In the human world, beyond the receptive and active systems—shared with all animals—man also possesses what Cassirer calls the symbolic system.
Human beings do not merely inhabit a broader and more complex reality; they live within an entirely new dimension of reality.
There is a clear difference between the reaction of humans to stimuli and that of other animals: in the case of animals, the reaction is immediate and direct, whereas in human beings it is postponed, interrupted, and delayed by a slow and intricate process of thought.
Man no longer lives in a purely physical universe but in a symbolic universe.
Physical reality recedes progressively as human beings develop their linguistic and symbolic capacities.

data.title: Differentiation of Languages in History: Positive or Negative Factor?
data.desc: The exact equivalent of a meaning in the language from which we are translating into our own language does not exist. Truth itself is multiple, and every culture possesses its own truth.

data.title: Is It Right for Education to Be Monolingual?

data.desc:
Imbalance Among Linguistic Minorities. German in South Tyrol: protected and respected.
Grecanico in Calabria: neglected.

During the Fascist period, linguistic minorities were actively marginalized.
A custom of the 1930s included the proverbial expression “you seem like a Greek to me”, used with derogatory intent. The use of languages other than Italian—often regarded as dialects—was perceived even by native speakers as a symbol of backwardness. Teachers punished students who were caught speaking a dialect in the classroom instead of Italian.

data.title: Manufacturing Consent
data.desc: Manufacturing Consent is a 1988 essay co-authored by Edward S. Herman and Noam Chomsky, in which the authors first develop the theory of the propaganda model and then apply it to a series of case studies.

data.title: Chomsky
data.desc: A professor of linguistics at MIT, he is recognized as the founder of generative-transformational grammar, often regarded as the most significant contribution to theoretical linguistics in the twentieth century.

In the book, Chomsky describes how the media filter information through five main mechanisms:
Private ownership of the media → economic interests shape the narrative.
Advertising as a source of funding → limits critical discourse toward sponsors.
Sources of information → journalists depend on governments and corporations.
Flak → criticisms and pressures directed at “uncomfortable” voices.
Dominant ideology (e.g., anti-communism, today the “war on terror”).
All these mechanisms operate at the linguistic level: they select words, frames, and silences.

Chomsky argues that language is never neutral:
In modern democracies, power is exercised more through the management of discourse than through force. Political and media language is simplified, manipulated, and “domesticated” to make certain ideas conceivable and others inconceivable.
This constitutes an implicit linguistic conflict: those who hold power determine which words, metaphors, and interpretive frames dominate the public sphere.

data.title: examples
data.desc:
Example: the use of the term “collateral damage” instead of “civilians killed” in war. The same fact, but language that neutralizes the ethical impact.
“Special operation” vs. “war” (Russia–Ukraine, 2022–present)
The Kremlin prohibits the use of the word “war” in Russian media; those who use it risk fines and imprisonment. The official narrative frames the conflict as a “special military operation.”
Here, the conflict is purely linguistic: defining the event one way or another shapes public perception.
If it is called a “war”, it implies aggression, invasion, and civilian casualties.
If it is called a “special operation”, it appears technical, limited, and legitimate.
“Migrants” vs. “invaders” (Europe and the USA, recent years)
In many political discourses, refugees or asylum seekers are labeled as “invaders”, “hordes”, or “illegals.”
Lexicon does not merely describe a phenomenon; it constructs a mental frame: migrants become a “military threat” rather than human beings.
The same individual can be a “refugee” (evoking compassion and the right to asylum) or an “illegal” (evoking illegality and danger).

data.title: The last speaker - South Africa's dying language
Sapir-Whorf examples and experiments
data.desc:
Guugu Yimithirr (Australia, Aboriginals of Queensland)
They do not use “right/left” for orientation. They rely solely on cardinal directions (north, south, east, west).
For them, a phrase such as “there is an ant on your right leg” becomes “there is an ant on your south leg,” which implies that they must always maintain an absolute sense of space. They perceive the world in geographic rather than egocentric terms.
Pirahã (Amazon, Brazil)
They lack precise numbers; only the concepts of “few” and “many” exist.
This alters the perception of quantity itself: for them, there is no “seven fish,” only “some fish.” They live in an immediate present, without the mathematical abstraction as understood in Western cultures.
Yupik (Inuit populations of Alaska)
They have over 90 terms for snow, not merely as a substance but as an event, process, or outcome.
For example, there are distinct words for “snow falling in large flakes,” “freshly fallen soft snow,” and “snow compacted by wind.” This is not simple synonymy but a perceptual mapping of the landscape, which is vital for them.
Dani (Papua New Guinea)
They have only two words for colors: “mili” (dark, cool: black, blue, green) and “mola” (light, warm: red, yellow, white).
They do not distinguish blue from green or yellow from white, because the chromatic world is reduced to two categories. Color is thus perceived as polarity rather than as a spectrum.
Aymara (Andes, Bolivia/Peru)
Their perception of time is inverted:
Past = in front (visible)
Future = behind (not visible)
For them, the future comes from behind the back, and the past lies before the eyes—a true reversal of our mental image of time.
Bassa (Liberia, Africa)
The language lacks words for numbers beyond five; quantities above this are expressed through combinations and metaphors.
This lexical limitation results in a very different perception of quantity: mathematics is not an innate tool in their worldview.
Kalaallisut (Greenland, Inuit)
Single word: “qangatasuukkuvimmuuriaqalaaqtunga” = “I have to go to the airport.”
The language is polysynthetic: a concept that requires an entire sentence in Italian is expressed as a single word. This alters the perception of what a “word” is and how compact a concept can be.

If for us language shapes reality, for the machine language is algorithm, instruction. Interaction is never neutral: it is a constant confrontation between two logics—one fluid and ambiguous (human), the other rigid and formal (machine). In the Three Laws of Robotics, language becomes crucial: the laws are written in verbal form, yet robots interpret them literally. This gives rise to numerous narrative conflicts: the ambiguity of human language versus the rigidity of logical interpretation.
This produces genuine linguistic conflicts: what a human intends to convey is not always what a machine “understands.”

Human beings communicate in a contextual and flexible manner: the meaning of a word shifts depending on the situation. Robots, by contrast, require precise rules. This gives rise to contradictions:
If a physician instructs a robot to administer a painful treatment to save a life, the robot must choose between causing pain (harm?) or allowing death (greater harm?).

data.title: Auxiliary language
data.desc:
An auxiliary language—or international auxiliary language, often abbreviated as IAL (from the English international auxiliary language, also referred to as auxlang)—is an artificial language created to facilitate communication between people of different nations who do not share a common language.
The term “auxiliary” implies that it is an additional language intended to be learned as a second language by all people worldwide, rather than a replacement for their native tongues. The term often refers specifically to constructed languages designed to facilitate international communication, such as Esperanto, Ido, Interlingua, Volapük, Glosa, and others.

Some argue that in the future Esperanto could serve as a solution for peoples who have experienced colonialism, as they might prefer a language not associated with any former colonial power. Others suggest that Latin could once again become an official language in Europe, at least for administrative purposes.
What if there were a single official language dedicated solely to administrative purposes?

data.title: Geopolitical Situations with Ongoing Linguistic Conflicts
serbian conflict
data.desc:
A special case is that of Serbia: Serbian is the official language of the state, but two scripts are in use:
Serbian Cyrillic (a variant of the Cyrillic alphabet, standardized by Vuk Karadžić in the nineteenth century).
Latin alphabet (widely used, especially in the media, on the internet, and in communication with foreign countries).
The Serbian constitution of 2006 establishes Cyrillic as the official script of the state, yet in practice the Latin script is used almost equally.

data.title: Belgian conflict
data.desc:
Belgium – Languages in Conflict: Dutch (Flemish) and French
Historically, French was the language of the elite and of politics, while Dutch was spoken by the Flemish majority.
Conflict: The Flemish population struggled to achieve equal linguistic status. Today, the country is divided into linguistic communities with substantial autonomy.
Geopolitical effects: Linguistic tensions have affected Belgium’s political stability, with governments frequently hampered by divisions between the north (Flemish) and the south (Walloon).

data.title: Canada
data.desc:
Canada (Québec) – Languages in Conflict: French and English
The population of Québec asserts French as a language of identity and resists the hegemony of English.
Conflict: Québec has enacted strict laws to protect the French language (e.g., Bill 101, which mandates the use of French in schools, businesses, and public signage).
Geopolitical effects: These tensions have given rise to separatist movements and referenda (1980 and 1995) on secession from Canada.

data.title: Spain
data.desc:
Spain – Languages in Conflict: Castilian (Spanish), Catalan, Basque, Galician
Under Franco, regional languages were repressed, and the use of Castilian was mandatory.
Conflict: Today, Catalan and Basque enjoy official regional status, yet political tensions persist regarding their protection and the perceived imposition of Castilian.
Geopolitical effects: Linguistic issues are closely intertwined with separatist movements, particularly in Catalonia.

data.title: Ukraine and Russia
data.desc:
Ukraine and Russia – Languages in Conflict: Ukrainian and Russian
After independence in 1991, Ukrainian was promoted as the official and identity language, while Russian remained widely spoken, particularly in the east and in Crimea.
Conflict: Language policies, including restrictions on the use of Russian in schools and media, were perceived by Moscow as a cultural attack.
Geopolitical effects: Language has become one of the justifications cited by Russia for military intervention and the annexation of Crimea (2014).

data.title: What if machines were to reprogram their own language? As a form of self-defense.
What if we no longer needed to communicate verbally? Or what if everyone spoke a single language?
First round of cards creation
data.desc: creation of some cards as a result of the first research

data.title: Different languages, different realities
data.desc:
Keywords: vision, truth 
Small description: Explore how different languages not only describe reality but also help constitute distinct versions of it; study how translation can fail, not due to mistakes, but because linguistic, cultural, and cognitive structures impose divergent worldviews. Analyze the conflicts that arise when these worldviews intersect or overlap.
Sapir–Whorf Hypothesis 
What are the cognitive (knowledge, memory, perception), social (identity, power, inequality), and political (law, education) effects of these multiple versions of reality?

“I limiti del mio linguaggio sono i limiti del mio mondo”.

data.title: Manufactoring consent - How politics influences the population through language
data.desc:
keywords: politics, people, control
small description: anguage is never neutral. Political and media language is simplified, manipulated, and “domesticated” to make certain ideas conceivable and others inconceivable. Those in power determine which words, metaphors, and interpretive frames dominate the public sphere.
For example, the use of the term “collateral damage” instead of “civilians killed” after the Vietnam War. The fact remains the same, yet language here serves to neutralize its ethical impact.
Deciding how to label an event is tantamount to deciding what kind of event exists.

data.title: Computers
data.desc:
keywords: control, Asimov
small description: The interaction between humans and machines is a constant confrontation between two logics: one fluid and ambiguous (human), the other rigid and formal (machine).
In the Three Laws of Robotics, language becomes crucial: the laws are written in verbal form, yet robots interpret them literally. This gives rise to numerous narrative conflicts, highlighting the ambiguity of human language versus the rigidity of logical interpretation.
This generates genuine linguistic conflicts: what a human intends to convey is not always what a machine “understands.”

What if a machine began to generate its own language, not to communicate with us, but to describe a world we cannot comprehend? 
What if machines reprogrammed their own language, cutting us out?

data.title: Buying Words
data.desc: Words are no longer a universal right, but a commodity to be purchased. Every sentence has a price; every word carries an economic and symbolic “weight.” The wealthy can afford articulate discourse, powerful slogans, even luxurious silences, while the poor must make do with discounted vocabulary, truncated phrases, and forced stammering. Communication becomes a market, and freedom of speech a privilege. Companies sell “expression packages,” emotions are measured in credits, and censorship is no longer necessary: it is the wallet that determines who has a voice and who remains silent.

data.title: The role of time
data.desc:
By learning to speak about the future in a different way, the brain reprograms itself.
This could represent the first psycho-physical evidence of the cognitive flexibility of bilinguals. We already know that bilinguals switch rapidly—and often unconsciously—between languages, a phenomenon known as code-switching. Yet, two different languages also carry with them distinct ways of perceiving the world and organizing the surrounding reality, a phenomenon that researchers struggled to explain for a long time.
Since time is such an abstract concept, the only way to speak about it is to borrow terms from a more concrete domain of experience.

data.title: What if it were possible to communicate through time?
Werther effect
data.desc:
keywords: silence and censorship
The term Werther effect refers to the phenomenon whereby news of a suicide published by mass media triggers a chain of subsequent suicides within society. In the absence of protective factors, the publicized suicide acts as a catalyst for other suicides among susceptible or suggestible individuals. This phenomenon is also commonly referred to as suicide contagion or imitative suicide.

data.title: Morality
data.desc:
Warning: the morality of your choices changes depending on the language you speak.
According to a scientific study, moral sentiment is not tied to personality but, more simply, to the language in which the moral dilemma is framed. When using one’s native tongue, individuals tend to be more sensitive.
Are you willing to sacrifice the life of one person to save ten? The answer depends on the language in which the question is posed. According to research published in Scientific American, morality is also a linguistic matter: an individual’s response to ethical dilemmas may vary depending on whether they are required to think in their mother tongue or in a language learned later in life, such as at school.

data.title: Silence
data.desc:
The Difference Between Silence and What We Cannot Hear
What is silence?
Is it simply what we fail to hear?
Is it what we choose not to consider as noise?
Do we, individually, decide what constitutes silence?
Silence is subjective: for me it arrives differently than it does for you.
From a scientific perspective, silence would correspond to 0 decibels—a condition that is, however, impossible in nature, not even in outer space.

data.title: reflection
data.desc:
Hearing a language – for me, who knows it, it carries meaning, but for someone who doesn’t, it’s just a collection of sounds.
Silence has now become a luxury → in an overly noisy society, silence turns into something you can buy (commodified like in the wellness industry).
A further provocation: selling silence is a bit like those who sell bottled air.

data.title: Paralanguage
data.desc:
Paralanguage refers to the non-verbal features of communication that modify or clarify the meaning of words.
Vocal: tone, volume, rhythm, pauses, inflection, timbre.
Non-vocal: laughter, sighs, yawns, coughs, strategic silences.
It is closely linked to non-verbal communication (gestures, proxemics, facial expressions), but it focuses on what accompanies the use of the voice.
The conflict arises from the fact that paralanguage is ambiguous:
it cannot be fully codified → it escapes total control;
but precisely this vagueness allows those in power to interpret it to their own advantage (e.g., labeling someone as “untrustworthy” based on their tone of voice).
Paralanguage is highly cultural and often ambiguous.

data.title: Languages are disappearing
data.desc:
Problem:
Today there are about 6,000 languages in the world.
But more than half could disappear by 2100.
Most people are not even aware of the linguistic richness that is being lost.
Causes:
Globalization and technology are pushing many communities to abandon their mother tongue.
English, Mandarin, and Spanish are considered more “useful.”
But:
Technology is not only a threat.
Example: the Cherokee are using social media, apps, and digital content to revitalize their language.
Other examples:
Goulburn Island (Australia): 400 inhabitants speak 10 different languages. Learning another person’s language is seen as a sign of respect.
Wales: children can choose between schools in English or Welsh. This supports the survival of the language.
“Losing one’s mother tongue often means losing cultural identity and becoming homogenized consumers, disconnected from one’s roots.”
Le lingue scompaiono perché le persone sono costrette ad abbandonare la loro lingua madre, spesso a causa di pressioni politiche.
Nel 1892, il generale USA Richard Henry Pratt dichiarò che per “salvare l’uomo” bisognava “uccidere l’Indiano”, cioè distruggere la cultura indigena attraverso l’assimilazione forzata.
Fino al 1978, il governo USA strappava i bambini indigeni alle loro famiglie, li mandava in collegi dove venivano puniti se parlavano la loro lingua madre: un genocidio culturale.

data.title: CHATBOTS, TRANSLATORS AND LANGUAGES
data.desc:
There are now earbuds that allow two foreigners to have a conversation translated simultaneously.
The latest inventions have created models that not only translate a language, but also understand it deeply and write it in a very “human-like” way. Life today is undoubtedly easier thanks to these translation systems.
A way to save languages

data.title: mental health dataq
data.desc: OMS

data.title: tomorrow's taboos
data.desc: “Which of today’s taboos will become accepted curiosities tomorrow, and which will instead turn into the new silences of the future?”

Romantic relationships with artificial intelligences / robots (emotional bonds, symbolic marriage)
Why it is a taboo: fear of replacement, moral and ontological issues.
Signals: increasingly empathetic devices, affective chatbots, ongoing ethical debates.
Probability: 5–10 years → 25%, 10–20 years → 55% — highly dependent on technological progress and regulation.

data.title: 1) Taboo as linguistic conflict: the case of rape
data.desc:
Definition of linguistic taboo
A taboo arises when a topic becomes socially or culturally unspeakable.
In the case of rape, violence is often shifted away from the linguistic plane: people speak about it without ever directly naming the act.
This creates a linguistic conflict: what happens in reality becomes unacceptable to articulate in public language.
Linguistic strategies of taboo
Euphemisms: “incident,” “violation,” “intimacy,” “inappropriate behavior.”
Semantic confusion: rape and sex mixed into a single lexical field (“sexual encounter,” “relation”).
Neutralization: impersonal narration (“what happened,” “the event”).
Removal of the subject: the perpetrator disappears; only “something that happened” to the victim remains.
Contexts in which the taboo operates
Media
Euphemisms reduce the perceived severity and shift attention from the violence to the victim’s morality (Ayia Napa case).
The taboo is used to make the news less “scandalous,” but also to normalize it.
Courts
Euphemistic language is also found in closing arguments, where the term “rape” should be explicit (Hoerl & MacLeod, 2025).
Consequence: reduced jury comprehension and retraumatization of victims.
Society / Communities
In contexts such as Pakistan, talking about rape is tied to “dishonor,” and blame is shifted onto the victim (Zaman et al., 2023).
Institutions
In cases like Penn State, systemic euphemisms covered up abuse and protected the organization’s reputation (Lucas & Fyke, 2013).
Effects on perception
Reduction of perceived severity: people do not fully recognize the violence.
Normalization: attenuated discourse makes rape appear “less extraordinary.”
Victim blaming: language that emphasizes the victim reinforces blame.
Online discourse ecology: softened language in the media → more hostile and uncivil comments directed at victims (Uncivil Reactions to Sexual Assault Online).
The core of the conflict
The linguistic taboo around rape is a social paradox:
the violence is acknowledged as extremely serious;
yet it cannot be clearly named.
This generates a conflict between:
The ethics of speaking: naming rape directly, bluntly.
The ethics of silence: protecting sensibilities, institutions, reputations, cultural norms.
Result: language itself becomes a battleground, where words determine the perception of reality.Definition of linguistic taboo
A taboo arises when a topic becomes socially or culturally unspeakable.
In the case of rape, violence is often shifted away from the linguistic plane: people speak about it without ever directly naming the act.
This creates a linguistic conflict: what happens in reality becomes unacceptable to articulate in public language.
Linguistic strategies of taboo
Euphemisms: “incident,” “violation,” “intimacy,” “inappropriate behavior.”
Semantic confusion: rape and sex mixed into a single lexical field (“sexual encounter,” “relation”).
Neutralization: impersonal narration (“what happened,” “the event”).
Removal of the subject: the perpetrator disappears; only “something that happened” to the victim remains.
Contexts in which the taboo operates
Media
Euphemisms reduce the perceived severity and shift attention from the violence to the victim’s morality (Ayia Napa case).
The taboo is used to make the news less “scandalous,” but also to normalize it.
Courts
Euphemistic language is also found in closing arguments, where the term “rape” should be explicit (Hoerl & MacLeod, 2025).
Consequence: reduced jury comprehension and retraumatization of victims.
Society / Communities
In contexts such as Pakistan, talking about rape is tied to “dishonor,” and blame is shifted onto the victim (Zaman et al., 2023).
Institutions
In cases like Penn State, systemic euphemisms covered up abuse and protected the organization’s reputation (Lucas & Fyke, 2013).
Effects on perception
Reduction of perceived severity: people do not fully recognize the violence.
Normalization: attenuated discourse makes rape appear “less extraordinary.”
Victim blaming: language that emphasizes the victim reinforces blame.
Online discourse ecology: softened language in the media → more hostile and uncivil comments directed at victims (Uncivil Reactions to Sexual Assault Online).
The core of the conflict
The linguistic taboo around rape is a social paradox:
the violence is acknowledged as extremely serious;
yet it cannot be clearly named.
This generates a conflict between:
The ethics of speaking: naming rape directly, bluntly.
The ethics of silence: protecting sensibilities, institutions, reputations, cultural norms.
Result: language itself becomes a battleground, where words determine the perception of reality.

data.title: Useful link for the Taboo as a linguistic conflict
data.desc: some links and sites that have been useful for the card's creation

data.title: Language and machines
data.desc:
Definition
In contemporary society, technology is taking on an increasingly important role, to the point where its application is being considered even in areas traditionally tied to human beings, such as psychotherapy.
Psychotherapy
In the near future, could machines replace the role of the psychotherapist?
Even today, there are chatbots and apps that provide psychological support, but the complete replacement of a human therapist would raise profound questions.
The problem: we do not speak the same language. A chatbot cannot fully understand us or replace a psychotherapist, especially because a machine tends to produce standardized, algorithmic language.
Human communication, on the other hand, is rich in nuances: pauses, metaphors, hesitations, slips, ambiguities — all of which the therapist interprets as valuable signals.
Paralanguage
Paralanguage is the set of non-verbal vocal elements that accompany words. It does not concern what we say, but how we say it:
Tone of voice
Volume
Intonation
Rhythm and speed
Pauses and silences
Extralinguistic sounds → sighs, laughter, throat clearing, murmurs.
Functions of paralanguage
Emotional → expresses feelings.
Relational → strengthens or weakens the relationship with the interlocutor (welcoming vs. detached tone).
Interpretive → gives meaning to words (a “thank you” can be sincere or ironic depending on tone).
Paralanguage in psychotherapy
In the context of psychotherapy, paralanguage plays an enormous role:
the therapist perceives anxiety, discomfort, hesitation from the patient’s rhythm and pauses;
the therapist’s tone of voice can convey warmth, calm, empathy;
silences and sighs become an integral part of the relationship.
For this reason, it is very difficult for a machine to replace a psychotherapist: AI can process words, but it struggles to interpret (or reproduce) paralinguistic nuances with authenticity.
The heart of the conflict
On one side, human language: alive, emotional, relational.
On the other, artificial language: neutral, calculated, impersonal.
This conflict would also affect the language of care: what will it mean to “speak with the therapist” if the interlocutor is an algorithm? Can we truly call the machine’s response “listening”? In this sense, the issue is not only technological but also cultural and linguistic: it concerns the value we assign to language as a tool for authentic human connection.

data.title: useful links to support the sapir worf theory
scenario
data.desc:
In a hypothetical future, the taboo reaches its extreme: words themselves seem to fall into the void. Newspapers carry headlines like “An unfortunate encounter” or “An unexpected episode,” while the real perpetrators vanish from the sentences. The subject of the action disappears; all that remains is “something that happened” to the victim. In everyday language, rape and sex blend indistinguishably into a single lexical field, and the gravity of the act becomes difficult to grasp.
The heart of the conflict emerges in daily conversations: those who attempt to name the violence are met with discomfort, as if they had broken an invisible rule, while those who remain silent do so to protect sensibilities, institutions, reputations. Words turn into a silent battleground, and reality itself bends to language: what is left unsaid loses weight, while what is hidden continues to exist — invisible yet present, like a shadow that everyone senses but no one dares to call by name.

data.title: Autism and communication difficulties
data.desc:
Definition of linguistic conflict
The conflict arises when the language of an autistic person does not align with the social and linguistic expectations of neurotypicals.
What the person wants to express or understand may appear unacceptable or incomprehensible in everyday communication.
Linguistic strategies and obstacles
Pragmatic difficulties: challenges in the social use of language (conversations, irony, metaphors).
Semantic problems: difficulties in understanding multiple meanings, abstract concepts, categorization.
Structural differences: grammar, syntax, phonology, and morphology may be limited or atypical.
Heterogeneity of profiles: some individuals are verbal and linguistically advanced; others are minimally verbal or nonverbal.
Comorbidities: language disorders, apraxia of speech, intellectual disability can worsen communication challenges.
Contexts in which the conflict emerges
School / Education
Standardized communication may prevent full participation.
Some children cannot make themselves understood by teachers or peers.
Society / Community
Difficulties in everyday social interactions → isolation or misunderstandings.
Work / Services
Need for augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) tools to effectively participate in interviews, instructions, or standardized protocols.
Effects on perception
Mutual frustration: for both the autistic person and neurotypical interlocutors.
Social barriers: stigma, misunderstanding, underestimation of actual abilities.
Practical impact: limits participation, learning, and social relationships.
The heart of the conflict
Linguistic conflict in autism arises when the autistic person has communicative abilities, but the social context does not recognize or understand them.
It is a tension between:
The ethics of expressing: communicating in the way most consistent with one’s own style.
The ethics of interpreting: society expects standardized communication.
Result: language becomes a site of struggle and mutual misunderstanding, with concrete effects on social and educational relationships.

data.title: List of modern linguistic mechanisms
data.desc:
1. Abbreviated and contracted writing
Acronyms and abbreviations: “cmq” (comunque = anyway), “xké” (perché = why/because), “tvb” (ti voglio bene = I love you), “grz” (grazie = thanks).
Graphic reduction for speed and practicality → born with SMS (where characters were limited) and continued today out of habit.
Use of numbers instead of letters or syllables: “6” = sei (you are/six), “x” = per (for), “tvtb” = ti voglio tanto bene (I love you very much).
2. Emojis and emoticons
They replace entire words or sentences, often becoming emotional markers (❤️ for love, 😂 for laughter).
Paralinguistic function: they fill the absence of tone, gestures, expressions.
They can become cultural symbols or even autonomous languages (e.g., telling a story only with emojis).
3. Anglicisms and hybridizations
Borrowings from English are increasingly widespread: “like,” “spoilerare” (to spoil), “cringe,” “shoppare” (to shop), “shippare” (to ship).
Hybridizations between languages (Itanglese, Spanglish, Hinglish).
On social media and in gaming, global slang expressions emerge, understood by international communities.
4. Memetics and ironic languages
Meme culture → recurring linguistic formulas (“ok boomer,” “sus” from Among Us, “based,” “ratio”).
Often quotations transformed into an internal code for those belonging to a community.
Memes create digital idioms that then spread to spoken language.
5. Written orality
Writing in chat tends to imitate speech:
use of ellipses “...” to simulate pauses;
repeated letters (“hellooo,” “nooo”) to mark intonation;
all caps to shout (“STOP”).
The distinction between written and spoken language becomes blurred.
6. Speed and simplification
Brevity is central: quick messages, broken up into multiple sends (the “rapid-fire messages” style of chat).
Reduction of punctuation, fragmented sentences, simplified grammar.
Priority: immediate effectiveness over correctness.
7. Digital neologisms
A constant creation of new words linked to online phenomena: “googlare” (to google), “instagrammabile” (instagrammable), “ghostare” (to ghost), “binge-watchare” (to binge-watch).
Hybrid verbs: often English root + Italian ending.
8. Multimodality and code hybridization
Text + image + audio/video → increasingly hybrid messages (stickers, gifs, voice notes).
The communicative act is no longer only written: it integrates multiple codes in a single flow.
9. Identity, community, and “group languages”
Each platform (TikTok, Twitch, Discord, Instagram) develops its own slang.
Language becomes a marker of belonging: you know you’re part of a group if you recognize and use certain expressions.
10. Side effects
Erosion of norms: grammar and spelling less respected.
Digital diglossia: learning to distinguish when to use “chat language” and when a formal register.
Fear of purists: but in reality these are historical phenomena → language always adapts to new media.

data.title: Homophones
data.desc:
Homophones are words that are pronounced in the same way but differ in meaning, spelling, or both. They are a common source of ambiguity and playfulness in language, but also of misunderstanding, making them an interesting case of linguistic conflict.
Definition
A homophone is a word that shares the same sound (phonetic form) with another but has a different meaning and often a different spelling.
Example: flower / flour, two / too / to, right / writ

data.title: Types of Homophones
data.desc:
In recent years, especially on social media platforms, users have begun to deliberately alter “sensitive” words in order to bypass automatic filters and moderation algorithms.
Letters are replaced with numbers or symbols → s3x, gr@pe, unalive.
Homophones or near-homophones are used → seggs instead of sex, unalive instead of dead.
Shared codes are invented within communities → for example, on TikTok, SA is used for sexual assault.

Why they create conflict
Ambiguity in oral communication: without visual context (spelling, sentence structure), it can be unclear which word is intended.
Second-language learners: homophones are especially confusing for those learning a new language.
Humor and wordplay: puns rely on homophones to create double meanings, but this can also generate miscommunication.
Cultural and social impact
Poetry and literature: poets exploit homophones for layered meanings.
Advertising and slogans: brands often use them for memorability (Sole food instead of soul food).
Taboo and censorship: in some cultures, homophones are avoided (e.g., in Chinese, some words associated with death have homophones used carefully in rituals).
Why it emerges
Moderation algorithms (TikTok, Instagram, YouTube, etc.) block or penalize content that contains words considered dangerous, violent, offensive, or related to sensitive topics.
Official goal → protect users, especially minors.
Real consequence → the “official” language gets censored or restricted, forcing users to reinvent it.
Linguistic effects
Semantic alteration: new words take on meanings they wouldn’t normally have (unalive becomes a synonym for “dead,” but with an ironic/detached tone).
Encoding and decoding: only those who know digital culture can understand the meaning; outsiders are excluded → creating a generational and cultural conflict.
Normalization: forms born to “avoid bans” become commonly used even outside platforms (e.g., unalive used in private chats or memes).
Shifting of the taboo: it is no longer the content itself that is taboo, but the word that expresses it.

data.title: Contextual Difference: spoken/written language vs. sung language
data.desc:
Context and perception:
Music is perceived as an art form, a creative expression.
Distinction between reality and fiction: When we listen to someone singing, we tend to think they are performing a role or telling a story, whereas in spoken or written language the same message can appear more “direct” and therefore more threatening or offensive.
Ambiguity:
Positive:
Role of art as a space for expressive freedom. Art allows the exploration of taboos: music (and art in general) is often considered a safe space where difficult, controversial, or socially unacceptable themes can be addressed. This is because it has a symbolic and cultural function, often aiming to raise awareness or shed light on uncomfortable realities.
Negative:
Ethical dilemma: The debate arises from the fact that, while being a space of freedom, art can also convey violent, discriminatory, or offensive messages, which may influence attitudes and behaviors.

data.title: The linguistic conflict in musical art
Algospeak research
data.desc:
Censorship is no longer carried out by a human being but by an algorithm. On social media, when I write or say a certain word, the system can automatically block, shadowban, or place warnings on my post.
This can happen even when the content is not harmful or violent but simply contains specific words.
The problem is that algorithms do not understand context.

data.title: Algospeak history
data.desc: The algorithms used by social media operate through blacklists. To circumvent them, users have created a new language called algospeak, exploiting the sound similarities between banned words and those currently allowed.

data.title: Algospeak ethical issues
data.desc:
But is it fair to have to speak in other languages just to bypass the algorithm? Can this really be considered freedom?
Having to alter the way you speak in order to discuss certain topics can be seen as a limitation of free speech. Greater transparency in algorithms and more human, context-aware moderation would be necessary.
The continuous use of codes and new languages could lead to an increasingly sharp divide between those who understand them and those who do not.
Different languages could emerge, difficult to decipher not only for algorithms but for many people as well.

data.title: Self-censorship
data.desc: Self-censorship and the fear of freely expressing our thoughts lie at the root of other major issues, such as the power of the media, public opinion, trends, and the increasingly entrenched distinction between so-called “strong thinking” and “weak thinking.” In a context and a world where the desire for dialogue intersects with the desire for fame, thoughts considered weak are censored to create a “spiral of silence.” All of this could represent a symptom of a transformation: that of our behaviors and our connections with society.

data.title: The Liquid Language Scenario
data.desc:
The Conflict
I want to speak, but my voice, my face, my gestures are intercepted by recognition systems that judge not only what I say, but how I say it. It’s no longer just forbidden words: even intonation, an extra pause, a grimace while uttering a neutral sentence are monitored.
Censorship
Control is not only linguistic but also paralinguistic. Every micro-expression is recorded and compared against emotional databases. “Suspicion of irony,” “potential sarcasm,” “destabilizing tone”: these become the new offenses.
Self-Censorship
I turn into an actor. My voice is flat, my face motionless, my body inert. I become a “real-life avatar”: my authentic self remains hidden beneath a surface trained not to betray emotions.
But this self-training is exhausting: I must not only change my words, I must rewire the way I feel and display emotions.
Linguistic Changes
Language transforms into something fluid and elusive.
Glitch languages emerge: silences, interruptions, distorted sounds used as secret codes.
Emojis are no longer icons but a full audiovisual dialect: an animation sequence becomes a sentence, a loop becomes protest.
Communities arise that communicate through facial filters or digital avatars: the face is a mask, the body a puppet.
Critical Question
Is it still freedom to speak with a thousand disguises, if every word is distorted to avoid betraying emotion?
Is the “liquid language” creativity, or merely a sophisticated survival mechanism?
Disruptive Point
A world where language is no longer stable or shared: each community invents an ephemeral code that lasts only until deciphered. Communication becomes a continuous escape.
The risk: there are no more “public words,” and therefore no common discourse. Everything is fragmented, volatile, irreconcilable.

data.title: What if the control of language in the dissemination of information were for our own good?
Manufactoring consent
data.desc:
Context
The language used to convey news and information has an effect on those who receive it. “The powerful” exploit this mechanism to report sensitive or thorny events that could reduce general consensus, using softened terms and euphemisms convenient to them.
Problem to Reflect On
How much do the words chosen to tell a story impact people?
A news story told with specific words creates a corresponding perception of reality closely tied to the language used, eliciting a range of psychological and emotional effects in the audience.
What if:
Post-war scenario: the population is traumatized, shattered by months of horrific accounts, unbearable images, memories that refuse to heal. People have seen too much, heard too much, and the future promises nothing good.
It is at this point that the government, caring as a watchful parent, decides to intervene. News is no longer reported in a raw manner but filtered, softened, made digestible. Civil massacres? “Collateral effects.” Internal attacks? “Operational incidents.” Hunger? “A temporary reconfiguration of dietary habits.”
All for our own good, of course. No need to get upset or suffer more than necessary: modern states know the priority is to guarantee their citizens a serene life, protected inside a bubble of safety and reassuring words. Because truth, let’s admit it, is overrated: much better to have information that is warm, comforting, and allows us to sleep peacefully.
Conflict: Definition, Cause, Agents, and Dynamics
Through the management of language, information is transmitted in ways that influence perception of reality, reinforce consensus, and shape collective opinion. The conflict lies between those who tamper with the truth of information for their own advantage and those who receive it, either recognizing its distortion or passively accepting it.
Different levels of conflict emerge: between those who manipulate information for their benefit and those who consume it, either critically acknowledging the distortion or passively absorbing it.
Identification of an Entity-Subject
The powerful, acting to safeguard mental health.

data.title: G-Rape Scenario
data.desc:
Context
Censorship is no longer carried out by a human being but by an algorithm.
On social media, when I write or say a certain word, the system can automatically block or shadowban content considered sensitive or dangerous.
How the algorithms work
Machine Learning: The algorithm is shown many videos already labeled as “violent,” and the system learns to recognize common characteristics.
Blacklist: A list of words, phrases, or content considered harmful.
This can happen even when the content is not harmful or violent but simply uses certain words, because in most cases algorithms cannot understand context.
This gave rise to algospeak: a coded way of communicating used by social media users to bypass content filters set by algorithmic codes — essentially the birth of a new dictionary.
Due to machine learning, as soon as a code word becomes widely used, it is recognized and added to the blacklist → continuous substitution and evolution of words.
One of the most used terms is “grape” (grape) as a replacement for the word “rape” and its corresponding emoji. However, algorithms are learning to block content with the word “grape” as well, as is happening with other algospeak terms.
→ Can we no longer post about grapes?!
Problem to Reflect On
Words and emojis used today in algospeak are beginning to be recognized as dangerous and are entering blacklists and social media word-recognition systems.
As a result, more and more everyday words become banned.
What If
What if the universe of the word grape were banned in all its forms?
With the progressive banning of the word grape, grapes and everything related to them disappear from the internet and all media. Saying “grape” no longer means talking about grapes but about rape, assuming all its social and semantic weight, and disappearing from our everyday speech.
Consequences? Nobody talks about grapes or anything derived from them: WINE.
Neither online nor in conversation.
The market for these products collapses.
Conflict: Definition, Cause, Agents, and Dynamics
Conflict arises between users who assign new meanings to words to escape censorship and the platforms that host these control algorithms.

data.title: Feedback scenarios
data.desc:
Revision Notes 30/09 – Summary & Suggestions
Scenario 1 – The Consensus Factory (Language Control for Our Own Good)
Current State: Already somewhat reflective of present reality. Language is used to sugarcoat events we don’t want to face.
Areas for Deepening:
Introduce a more logical, forward-looking step that stimulates reflection beyond the immediate scenario.
The scenario could be made more subversive or thought-provoking.
Consider how audiences might imagine this situation: risk of landing between partial self-censorship (as already occurs today, e.g., TV scheduling, audience targeting).
Use data to support the scenario; this is a rich area to develop.
Tone: Avoid banalities, refine and focus on subtlety. Make it sophisticated.
Scenario 2 – Grapes / Algospeak
Current State: The linguistic mechanism is interesting, but focusing only on “grape” is too narrow.
Suggestions:
Provide a broad explanation of the system before diving into specific cases.
Begin showing how other words could evolve into algospeak, especially those at risk of being banned.
Include quantitative data to contextualize the phenomenon (not necessarily for presentation, but useful for internal understanding).
Problematic Insight: Society is becoming overly sensitive; a portion of the vocabulary is increasingly unusable.
Points of Interest:
Phonetic connections (homophony) are especially compelling.
Refine the scenario: show how object iconography disappears (e.g., corn is no longer eaten) without overstating apocalyptic market collapse. Make the audience feel immersed.
Convince the audience: does the word exist or not? Clarify with careful examples.
Conflict: Should be linguistically focused. Shadowbanning is happening for words that aren’t extreme. Sensitivity and “fear” drive the tension.
Scenario Refinement:
Use glyphs or symbols that hint at “suspicious” content.
Map reality to the scenario clearly (linear points A, B, C, D). Provide context and preliminary research examples.
What If?
What if self-censorship leads to…?
What if the replacement of sensitive terms leads to…?
Overall Recommendations:
Make conflicts explicit and easily understandable, especially for audiences unfamiliar with the topic.
Avoid extreme or banal conclusions; aim for nuanced, believable scenarios.
Maintain a balance between linguistic theory, technical mechanism (algorithms, blacklists), and human/social impact.
If you want, I can rewrite both scenarios in a fully refined English version, ready for presentation, incorporating these revision notes and the “What If” reflections. Do you want me to do that next?

data.title: Perception of reality
data.desc:
The choice of words in news reporting strongly shapes public perception through emotional framing, influencing reactions more than the facts themselves.
Studies on vaccine reporting showed mainstream media framed vaccines with positive emotions, while alternative sources often conveyed sadness or fear, particularly for AstraZeneca. Key terms like “thrombosis” and “death” were resemanticized, with emotional connotations shifting depending on the source.
A study of 372 crowd-incident articles (1900–2019) revealed lexical and emotional shifts over time. Terms like “stampede” were gradually replaced by “crowd crush,” and a dominant tone of fear/alarm persisted across decades, intensifying in modern reporting. This demonstrates that media leverage strong emotions to capture attention and shape public perception, often employing sensationalistic language rather than neutral facts.

data.title: Concretizing Algospeak Hypotheses
data.desc: Provide concrete examples with sentences and transformations - e.g., written conversation in various degrees of algospeak. We are still in the realm of hypotheses - struggling to make it concrete. Conflictual dimension must be maintained. How do I represent it? - e.g., anger project. Imagine forms of depiction - to understand if it is credible and if it works.

data.title: Language Adaptation and User Perception
data.desc:
The text suggests expanding the project's scope beyond media to include interpersonal communication, noting that people naturally adjust language for different audiences (e.g., children vs. peers) to either soothe or manipulate emotions (e.g., creating urgency). It defines naming and language as a "battlefield" that actively constructs reality.

Practically, there is a need to create visual aids like storyboards to define the user experience. A specific challenge is identified: currently, users only see their personalized version, masking the conflict with other perspectives. The goal is for the user to intuitively grasp—without external explanation—that their personal parameters are what shape the narrative, proving that language creates reality.

data.title: The Algospeak Conflict and Future Scenarios
data.desc: The notes analyze the tension between user expression and algorithmic control. Users adopt "algospeak" (e.g., using "unalive") to avoid censorship, but this "sterilizes" language, reduces the impact of reality, and destabilizes shared meaning. The author envisions a future where moderation is hyper-adaptive, forcing language to update every second like software. Two technical solutions are brainstormed: a tool that encodes messages based on the rules of the exact moment (decodable via metadata), or a user-side tool to decode the constantly shifting vocabulary of others, bypassing the platform's censorship.

data.title: The emotional linguistic mediation platform
data.desc: The text describes a future scenario centered on a start-up that turns news into a "therapeutic good." To combat global cognitive fatigue and information saturation, the company uses AI and biometric data to rewrite news in real-time, adapting the language to the user's specific stress tolerance and emotional state. While the stated mission is to "humanize information" and protect mental health, the underlying implication is a "linguistic conflict": users consensually surrender complexity and delegate the regulation of their emotional reality to an algorithm, creating an information bubble designed solely not to hurt them.

data.title: Media Framing and Linguistic Bias in the Israel-Palestine Conflict
data.desc:
This document analyzes the "framing" of the Israel-Palestine conflict by comparing two Italian newspapers, Corriere della Sera and Libero Quotidiano. Through word frequency analysis (Table 5) and headline comparison, it demonstrates how linguistic choices shape reality.

Libero uses polarized language, focusing on "Hamas," "Attacks," and security, prioritizing the Israeli viewpoint.

Corriere focuses on "Diplomacy," "International Organizations," and institutional discourse.

The text also provides a theoretical example of how language sanitizes reality in international politics: labeling a combat mission as "Peacekeeping" or "Stabilization" instead of "Military Intervention" changes the public's perception from one of violence to one of neutrality, fitting the user's broader theme of how language constructs (or distorts) reality.

data.title: Linguistic Framing in Rape Trials
data.desc: The text analyzes how lexical choices in legal settings manipulate the perception of reality, specifically in rape trials. Citing studies by Loftus & Palmer, Pritchard, and Trinch, it highlights that explicit terms like "rape" are often banned to protect the accused's innocence, a restriction unique to this crime. Consequently, the violence of the act is obscured: judges and lawyers frequently use "erotic," "neutral," or "euphemistic" language (over 80% of references), rather than direct ("orthophemistic") terms. The text also notes a classification system for these words (sexual, violent, physical, disapproving, oxymoronic) and a "spectrum of directness," showing that legal language systematically softens the reality of sexual violence.

data.title: First brand identity feedback
data.desc: These notes reframe the project's identity: the fictional entity should operate and present itself specifically as a linguistic arms dealer. The core concept is that words are weapons, and the "parameters" chosen by users are akin to selecting a specific model of weaponry. A distinction is drawn between the "Machine" (an installation/marketing tool used to project the company's vision) and the actual "Weapons" (the linguistic tools sold to different clients, from state to civilians). The summary questions the scale of production (one vs. many weapons) and emphasizes the mission of "helping to create a different world" through linguistic control.

data.title: Decision, evolution and application of our logo
FRAGMA: Brand Identity and Copywriting Strategy
data.desc: The document outlines the branding and content strategy for "FRAGMA," a fictional corporation that treats language as "engineered weaponry." The brand presents itself as a scientific, authoritative, and determined entity offering "strategic linguistics" to governments (via SuperComputers) and corporations/individuals (via limited devices). The core philosophy is that reality should not be passively experienced but actively constructed and controlled through specific "rhetorical artifacts" (e.g., polarization, urgency). The proposed marketing copy emphasizes control, precision, and the power to define reality rather than discuss it, targeting an elite audience while treating the general public as subjects of this linguistic engineering.

data.title: Copywriting update
data.desc: We understood that our payoff and our claim weren't enough strong, so we tried to do something more

data.title: Copywriting update
data.desc: Our payoff was developed through a benchmark analysis of leading defense companies. It emphasizes power and control through a sophisticated lexicon, focusing on strategic authority while maintaining a refined and non-explicit tone.

Testing the creation of graphic artifacts based on the ASCII character set. Visual inputs are translated into ASCII image reconstructions using character-density mapping and grid-based raster techniques. The resulting graphics adopt a distinctly digital aesthetic, enhanced through controlled color application.

data.title: Some ASCII reference
data.desc: we've collected some ascii reference to complete our style

data.title: what if language was engineered as a weapon
Copywriting update
data.desc: After an initial phase using 'Power of words', we shifted our brand messaging from the conceptual 'Power of words' to the more impactful 'Words to dominate'. This change aligns our visual identity with a more aggressive market positioning, emphasizing mastery and results.

data.title: Positioning
data.desc: We have positioned our operations at the intersection of the virtual domain, the intangible space where information flows, and the cognitive domain, the environment where information is processed to drive decision-making.

data.title: STORYTELLING: research
data.desc: research about

data.title: Resource Definition
data.desc: Language as an Engineered Weapon: the evolution of language from a simple communication tool to advanced military technology. Words are treated as high-potential strategic assets, becoming the foundational pillar of modern cognitive warfare.

data.title: Domain Analysis
data.desc: Mapping the Cognitive Battlefield: Identification of the human mind as the primary operational theater. Conflict shifts from the physical dimension to a systemic environment where three planes interact: Physical (action), Virtual (information), and Cognitive (processing).

data.title: operational process
data.desc: Fragmentation and Reality Reconstruction: Deployment of linguistic technologies to dismantle the target's perceived reality. Once perception is fragmented, a "tailored reality" is reconstructed, ensuring the client’s narrative dominance and the affirmation of their strategic truth.

data.title: research on war domain
data.desc: We conducted a comprehensive analysis of contemporary warfare doctrines. By examining numerous academic and technical papers, we explored the intersection of the cognitive, physical, and virtual domains to define our strategic positioning within these multi-dimensional environments.

data.title: PRODUCT PORTFOLIO
data.desc: We have developed a product portfolio that integrates our linguistic engineering technology into scalable solutions, modeled directly on the needs of strategic partners. Assets are categorized and prioritized based on their cognitive impact power and the specific target profile

data.title: neuro lexis
data.desc: We defined neuro lexis as a neural interface capable of reading and modifying language-based thoughts. We designed it to intercept and rewrite a person’s words and intentions directly within the brain.
We studied scientific papers and technical videos of medical prototypes. We analyzed these technologies to understand how to repurpose a medical device into a strategic control tool.

data.title: project synapse-overlay
data.desc: We defined project synapse-overlay as software that intercepts and alters digital messages in real-time. We developed it to manipulate how people react to information by influencing their emotions through language.
We researched online studies and white papers on social media algorithms. We gathered data on how words can alter brain chemistry to transform a writing tool into a psychological weapon.

data.title: reasearch on products
data.desc: Research into the product portfolios and catalogs of leading arms companies to extract communication models, technical frameworks, and aesthetic standards. The objective is to analyze and acquire key sector insights in order to replicate their specialized language and authoritative positioning within our own strategic offering.

data.title: Material List & Contextual Mapping
data.desc: We created a list of materials to prepare, matching each one to the specific context in which it would be used

data.title: infographics making
data.desc: For each of our core themes, we created dedicated infographics capable of explaining the logical and scientific foundations of our projects. These visuals translate complex concepts into clear technical diagrams

data.title: video n.1
data.desc: We produced the first version of the video using After Effects for editing and digital effects, integrating AI-generated content. This allowed us to create complex, modern visuals consistent with the project's high-tech identity.

data.title: thirty sec teaser reserch and collecting
data.desc: We developed an initial storyboard for the video teaser, based on our core corporate values and the message we wanted to convey. To define the tone and style, we drew inspiration from leading defense companies like Palantir, aiming for a high-tech and authoritative aesthetic.

data.title: thirty sec teaser reserch and collecting
data.desc: Analyzing the weaknesses of the first video, we designed a new, more effective storyboard. In this phase, we decided to use a voice-over as the primary guide, writing a specific script to set the narrative pace and make the message clearer and more engaging.

data.title: video n.2
data.desc: We completed the production of the new video version, synchronizing the visuals with the vocal track. This final step allowed us to consolidate the union between the power of language (the narrated text) and the visual impact of our technology.

data.title: research on comunication material
data.desc: We researched the actual documents and visual materials used in scientific, military, and engineering fields. We analyzed technical diagrams, manuals, and operational interfaces to understand how professionals in these sectors communicate. Our goal was to replicate this visual style to make our project look as realistic and credible as possible.

data.title: research on infographics
data.desc: We conducted specific research into infographics used in engineering and military fields, analyzing flowcharts, ballistic diagrams, and targeting interfaces. We studied how these visuals synthesize complex data in a cold, functional manner to extract a visual language of coordinates, vectors, and technical legends.
